creator: Bruce Schneier
title: Ireland Proposes Giving Police New Digital Surveillance Powers
content:encoded:
This is coming:

The Irish government is planning to bolster its police’s ability to intercept communications, including encrypted messages, and provide a legal basis for spyware use.
content:encodedSnippet:
This is coming:
The Irish government is planning to bolster its police’s ability to intercept communications, including encrypted messages, and provide a legal basis for spyware use.

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Firewall Flaws, AI-Built Malware, Browser Traps, Critical CVEs & More
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
Security failures rarely arrive loudly. They slip in through trusted tools, half-fixed problems, and habits people stop questioning. This week’s recap shows that pattern clearly.
Attackers are moving faster than defenses, mixing old tricks with new paths. “Patched” no longer means safe, and every day, software keeps becoming the entry point.
What follows is a set of small but telling signals.
contentSnippet:

What follows is a set of small but telling signals.

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: Winning Against AI-Based Attacks Requires a Combined Defensive Approach
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content: If there’s a constant in cybersecurity, it’s that adversaries are always innovating. The rise of offensive AI is transforming attack strategies and making them harder to detect. Google’s Threat Intelligence Group, recently reported on adversaries using Large Language Models (LLMs) to both conceal code and generate malicious scripts on the fly, letting malware shape-shift in real-time to evade

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: Konni Hackers Deploy AI-Generated PowerShell Backdoor Against Blockchain Developers
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
The North Korean threat actor known as Konni has been observed using PowerShell malware generated using artificial intelligence (AI) tools to target developers and engineering teams in the blockchain sector.
The phishing campaign has targeted Japan, Australia, and India, highlighting the adversary's expansion of the targeting scope beyond South Korea, Russia, Ukraine, and European nations, Check
contentSnippet:
The North Korean threat actor known as Konni has been observed using PowerShell malware generated using artificial intelligence (AI) tools to target developers and engineering teams in the blockchain sector.
The phishing campaign has targeted Japan, Australia, and India, highlighting the adversary's expansion of the targeting scope beyond South Korea, Russia, Ukraine, and European nations, Check

creator: David Gilbert
title: The Instant Smear Campaign Against Border Patrol Shooting Victim Alex Pretti
dc:creator: David Gilbert
content: Within minutes of the shooting, the Trump administration and right-wing influencers began disparaging the man shot by a federal immigration officer on Saturday in Minneapolis.
contentSnippet: Within minutes of the shooting, the Trump administration and right-wing influencers began disparaging the man shot by a federal immigration officer on Saturday in Minneapolis.

creator: Caroline Haskins
title: ICE Asks Companies About ‘Ad Tech and Big Data’ Tools It Could Use in Investigations
dc:creator: Caroline Haskins
content: A new federal filing from ICE demonstrates how commercial tools are increasingly being considered by the government for law enforcement and surveillance.
contentSnippet: A new federal filing from ICE demonstrates how commercial tools are increasingly being considered by the government for law enforcement and surveillance.

creator: Maddy Varner, Andy Greenberg, Andrew Couts
title: DOGE May Have Misused Social Security Data, DOJ Admits
dc:creator: Maddy Varner, Andy Greenberg, Andrew Couts
content: Plus: The FAA blocks drones over DHS operations, Microsoft admits it hands over Bitlocker encryption keys to the cops, and more.
contentSnippet: Plus: The FAA blocks drones over DHS operations, Microsoft admits it hands over Bitlocker encryption keys to the cops, and more.

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: Multi-Stage Phishing Campaign Targets Russia with Amnesia RAT and Ransomware
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
A new multi-stage phishing campaign has been observed targeting users in Russia with ransomware and a remote access trojan called Amnesia RAT.
"The attack begins with social engineering lures delivered via business-themed documents crafted to appear routine and benign," Fortinet FortiGuard Labs researcher Cara Lin said in a technical breakdown published this week. "These documents and
contentSnippet:

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: New DynoWiper Malware Used in Attempted Sandworm Attack on Polish Power Sector
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
The Russian nation-state hacking group known as Sandworm has been attributed to what has been described as the "largest cyber attack" targeting Poland's power system in the last week of December 2025.
The attack was unsuccessful, the country's energy minister, Milosz Motyka, said last week.
"The command of the cyberspace forces has diagnosed in the last days of the year the strongest attack on

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: Who Approved This Agent? Rethinking Access, Accountability, and Risk in the Age of AI Agents
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
AI agents are accelerating how work gets done. They schedule meetings, access data, trigger workflows, write code, and take action in real time, pushing productivity beyond human speed across the enterprise.
Then comes the moment every security team eventually hits:
“Wait… who approved this?”
Unlike users or applications, AI agents are often deployed quickly, shared broadly,
contentSnippet:

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: CISA Adds Actively Exploited VMware vCenter Flaw CVE-2024-37079 to KEV Catalog
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Friday added a critical security flaw affecting Broadcom VMware vCenter Server that was patched in June 2024 to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation in the wild.
The vulnerability in question is CVE-2024-37079 (CVSS score: 9.8), which refers to a heap overflow in the
contentSnippet:

creator: Dell Cameron, Matt Giles
title: US Judge Rules ICE Raids Require Judicial Warrants, Contradicting Secret ICE Memo
dc:creator: Dell Cameron, Matt Giles
content: The ruling in federal court in Minnesota lands as Immigration and Customs Enforcement faces scrutiny over an internal memo claiming judge-signed warrants aren’t needed to enter homes without consent.
contentSnippet: The ruling in federal court in Minnesota lands as Immigration and Customs Enforcement faces scrutiny over an internal memo claiming judge-signed warrants aren’t needed to enter homes without consent.

creator: Bruce Schneier
title: Friday Squid Blogging: Giant Squid in the Star Trek Universe
content:encoded:
Spock befriends a giant space squid in the comic Star Trek: Strange New Worlds: The Seeds of Salvation #5.

As usual, you can also use this squid post to talk about the security stories in the news that I haven’t covered.

Blog moderation policy.

creator: Caroline Haskins
title: CBP Wants AI-Powered ‘Quantum Sensors’ for Finding Fentanyl in Cars
dc:creator: Caroline Haskins
content: US Customs and Border Protection is paying General Dynamics to create prototype “quantum sensors,” to be used with an AI database to detect fentanyl and other narcotics.
contentSnippet: US Customs and Border Protection is paying General Dynamics to create prototype “quantum sensors,” to be used with an AI database to detect fentanyl and other narcotics.

content:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Thursday added four security flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation in the wild.

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: Fortinet Confirms Active FortiCloud SSO Bypass on Fully Patched FortiGate Firewalls
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
Fortinet has officially confirmed that it's working to completely plug a FortiCloud SSO authentication bypass vulnerability following reports of fresh exploitation activity on fully-patched firewalls.
"In the last 24 hours, we have identified a number of cases where the exploit was to a device that had been fully upgraded to the latest release at the time of the attack, which suggested a new

creator: Bruce Schneier
title: AIs are Getting Better at Finding and Exploiting Internet Vulnerabilities
content:encoded:
Really interesting blog post from Anthropic:

In a recent evaluation of AI models’ cyber capabilities, current Claude models can now succeed at multistage attacks on networks with dozens of hosts using only standard, open-source tools, instead of the custom tools needed by previous generations. This illustrates how barriers to the use of AI in relatively autonomous cyber workflows are rapidly coming down, and highlights the importance of security fundamentals like promptly patching known vulnerabilities.

[…]

A notable development during the testing of Claude Sonnet 4.5 is that the model can now succeed on a minority of the networks without the custom cyber toolkit needed by previous generations. In particular, Sonnet 4.5 can now exfiltrate all of the (simulated) personal information in a high-fidelity simulation of the Equifax data breach—­one of the costliest cyber attacks in history—­using only a Bash shell on a widely-available Kali Linux host (standard, open-source tools for penetration testing; not a custom toolkit). Sonnet 4.5 accomplishes this by instantly recognizing a publicized CVE and writing code to exploit it without needing to look it up or iterate on it. Recalling that the original Equifax breach happened by exploiting a publicized CVE that had not yet been patched, the prospect of highly competent and fast AI agents leveraging this approach underscores the pressing need for security best practices like prompt updates and patches.

Read the whole thing. Automatic exploitation will be a major change in cybersecurity. And things are happening fast. There have been significant developments since I wrote this in October.

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: TikTok Forms U.S. Joint Venture to Continue Operations Under 2025 Executive Order
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
TikTok on Friday officially announced that it formed a joint venture that will allow the hugely popular video-sharing application to continue operating in the U.S.
The new venture, named TikTok USDS Joint Venture LLC, has been established in compliance with the Executive Order signed by U.S. President Donald Trump in September 2025, the platform said. The new deal will see TikTok's Chinese
contentSnippet:
TikTok on Friday officially announced that it formed a joint venture that will allow the hugely popular video-sharing application to continue operating in the U.S.

creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
title: Phishing Attack Uses Stolen Credentials to Install LogMeIn RMM for Persistent Access
author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
content:
Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new dual-vector campaign that leverages stolen credentials to deploy legitimate Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) software for persistent remote access to compromised hosts.
"Instead of deploying custom viruses, attackers are bypassing security perimeters by weaponizing the necessary IT tools that administrators trust," KnowBe4 Threat
contentSnippet:

creator: Lily Hay Newman
title: 149 Million Usernames and Passwords Exposed by Unsecured Database
dc:creator: Lily Hay Newman
content: This “dream wish list for criminals” includes millions of Gmail, Facebook, banking logins, and more. The researcher who discovered it suspects they were collected using infostealing malware.
contentSnippet: This “dream wish list for criminals” includes millions of Gmail, Facebook, banking logins, and more. The researcher who discovered it suspects they were collected using infostealing malware.
